Mn-based catalysts exhibit remarkable NH3-SCR activity. However, their single-component oxides are limited by insufficient surface acidity and poor resistance to H2O and SO2. Therefore, enhancing their surface acidity and improving their resistance to water and sulfur is a meaningful research topic. A series of MnCoNi-xS catalysts were fabricated through treatment of MnCoNi (prepared via a solvent-free method) with sulfuric acid at varying concentrations. This study methodically examines how varying concentrations of sulfuric acid affect the SCR activity and H2O and SO2 durability of MnCoNi ternary catalysts. The comprehensive characterization analyses demonstrate that applying varied concentrations of sulfuric acid during treatment can generate differentiated high-activity domains. Appropriate sulfuric acid treatment can enhance the surface acidity, specific surface area, and redox properties of MnCoNi catalysts, thereby promoting their denitrification performance. Ultimately, the MnCoNi-xS catalyst ​maintained exceptional catalytic activity even under prolonged exposure to H₂O and SO₂. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Acid treatment Catalyst MnCoNi-xS NH₃-SCR Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions can be categorized into natural and anthropogenic sources. Natural emissions primarily result from the nitrogen cycle processes in nature, specifically through microbial decomposition in soil and marine ecosystems. Anthropogenic emissions are closely linked to industrialization, predominantly originating from high-temperature fossil fuel combustion, with transportation, electricity generation, and industrial activities collectively contributing nearly 81 % of total emissions, followed by approximately 15 % from smaller fossil fuel combustion sources, and only about 4 % from natural sources [1]. The 14th Five-Year Plan of China has identified nitrogen oxides (NOx) as the most critical air pollutant. In 2020, the NOx emissions in China surpassed 10 million tons, with nitrate concentrations in PM2.5 exceeding sulfate levels in many major urban areas. As NOx emissions continue to rise, the composition of acid rain pollution has shifted from a sulfate-dominated pattern to a mixed type characterized by both sulfate and nitrate [2]. Therefore, controlling NOx emissions remains a critical priority. NH3-SCR technology, widely recognized as a highly effective approach for NOx abatement owing to its superior removal efficiency, excellent selectivity, and technical maturity, fundamentally depends on the development and optimization of catalysts [3–5]. V₂O₅-WO₃/TiO₂ vanadium catalysts constitute the mainstream commercial NH₃-SCR technology, exhibiting superior NOx removal capability at 300–400 °C [6] and has achieved large-scale industrial deployment [7]. However, vanadium-based catalysts suffer from inherent drawbacks, including poor low-temperature performance [8], biological toxicity of vanadium [9], and high susceptibility to poisoning and deactivation caused by SO₂ and ash deposits at high temperatures [10]. Among various metal catalysts, MnOx has attracted significant attention due to its diverse oxidation states (e.g., Mn²⁺, Mn³⁺, Mn⁴⁺) and exceptional redox properties [11]. Li et al. prepared and evaluated four different crystal structures of MnO₂ catalysts, and found that the γ-MnO₂ catalyst exhibited outstanding performance in the catalytic conversion of NO and CO due to its abundant surface Oβ and Mn⁴⁺ species as well as excellent redox properties [12]. Similarly, Ren et al. found that the CuOₓ/α-MnO₂ bifunctional catalyst could achieve 81 % NO conversion and 96 % CO removal at 150 °C through strong Mn-Cu interactions, further demonstrating the superior performance of Mn-based catalysts [3]. Nevertheless, MnOx catalysts face challenges including insufficient surface acidity [13] and poor resistance to water and sulfur [14], which severely limit their commercial application. To overcome these challenges, elemental doping strategies have proven effective in boosting catalytic performance. Researchers have conducted in-depth investigations into the formation mechanism and evolution process of N₂O over spherical MnFeOₓ catalysts, with comparative analyses against pristine MnOₓ and FeOₓ catalysts. The results demonstrate that the MnFeOₓ catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity compared to single-component oxide catalysts [15]. Chen's team developed Sm-modified MnFeO₄ catalysts, where the electronic migration between Sm-Mn-Fe not only enhanced oxygen vacancy concentration and NH₃ adsorption capacity, but also achieved superior sulfur resistance by inducing preferential reaction of Fe/Sm with SO₂ [16]. Chen et al. fabricated a porous spherical MnCoOx catalyst with high low-temperature denitration efficiency and robust SO₂ tolerance [17], attributed to the strong Mn-Co interaction that generates enhanced Lewis acid sites on MnCoOx, thereby suppressing SO₂ adsorption. Additionally, Wan et al. prepared a Mn-Ni bimetallic oxide catalyst via co-precipitation and demonstrated that the introduction of Ni effectively increases both the surface density and Lewis acidity of acid sites. The electron transfer between Mn and Ni ions creates a synergistic catalytic effect, leading to improved low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) performance [18]. It is well established that appropriate surface acidity of SCR catalysts facilitates ammonia adsorption and prevents high-temperature ammonia oxidation, thereby enhancing catalytic performance.Previous studies have explored acid treatment strategies to modify catalysts. For instance, Lian et al. treated CeO₂ with sulfuric acid via impregnation to prepare xH₂SO₄/CeO₂ catalysts, demonstrating that sulfuric acid treatment enhanced surface acidity and significantly improved NOx conversion and N₂ selectivity at high temperatures [19]. Li et al. utilized phosphoric acid to modify V-Ce-Ox catalysts, enriching acidic sites and suppressing SO₂ oxidation, thereby boosting low-temperature SCR activity and sulfur resistance [20]. Dong et al. utilized HPMo as an acidic modifier to prepare MnCe-HPMo catalysts with different HPMo loadings. The enhanced SCR performance stemmed from greater acid site density and improved NH₃ adsorption capacity, thereby increasing surface NH₃ availability for the SCR reaction [21]. Yao et al. synthesized various acid-pretreated CeO₂ catalysts, revealed that sulfuric acid-treated CeO₂-S exhibited optimal NH₃-SCR performance due to enriched surface acid sites and improved reducibility [22]. Song et al. developed sulfated CeO₂ catalysts via sol-gel synthesis, achieving enhanced low-temperature activity (150–450 °C) through increased acidic sites [23]. Collectively, these studies demonstrate that the use of acid-treated catalysts is an effective approach to improve NH3-SCR performance. Further investigations by Gao et al. demonstrated that sulfuric acid pretreatment alleviated Na⁺ induced degradation of denitrification efficiency and N₂ selectivity by modulating catalyst surface properties [24]. Li et al. impregnated (Ce,La)CO₃F with sulfuric acid solutions of varying concentrations, yielding SO₄²⁻/(Ce,La)CO₃F catalysts with strengthened acidic sites, elevated adsorbed oxygen content, and enhanced low-temperature selective catalytic reduction performance and sulfur tolerance [25]. The results indicate that sulfuric acid-treated catalysts can enrich active sites and enhance SCR activity. While previous works have examined sulfuric acid modification, the critical role of treatment concentration in tailoring catalyst performance has been largely overlooked. Consequently, systematic investigation of sulfuric acid concentration effects on both NH₃-SCR activity and reaction mechanisms in Mn-based catalysts remains crucial for advancing catalyst design. This study synthesized a MnCoNi catalyst using a solvent-free approach followed by acid treatment with different concentrations of sulfuric acid solutions. A combination of advanced characterization techniques—including XRD, BET, XPS, H₂-TPR, NH₃-TPD, and in-situ DRIFTS—was employed to investigate the influence of sulfuric acid treatment on surface properties, redox behavior, and acidic site distribution. By correlating these structural and chemical insights with SCR activity measurements, we elucidated the mechanistic role of sulfuric acid pretreatment in enhancing the catalytic performance of the MnCoNi system. These results offer new insights and a theoretical basis for developing efficient, economical, and stable Mn-based SCR catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Preparation of MnCoNi catalyst via solvent-free method [26]. Analytical-grade reagents with > 99 % purity were used: Mn(CH₃COO)₂·4H₂O (Mn source), Co(NO₃)₃·6H₂O (Co source), Ni(CH₃COO)₂·4H₂O (Ni source), and KMnO₄ (additive). Initially, stoichiometric amounts of potassium, manganese, cobalt, and nickel precursors (molar ratio K:Mn:Co:Ni = 3:2:2:2) were weighed and transferred into an agate mortar. The mixture was homogenized by manual grinding for 20 min. The resulting powder was then dried at 80 °C for 12 h. To eliminate soluble impurities, the dried sample was repeatedly washed with deionized water until a clear filtrate was obtained. After washing, the purified product was further dried at 80 °C overnight to yield the final MnCoNi catalyst precursor. The prepared MnCoNi catalyst precursor was subjected to acid treatment by immersion in sulfuric acid solutions with concentrations of 0.005 mol/L, 0.01 mol/L, 0.02 mol/L, 0.05 mol/L, 0.1 mol/L, 0.2 mol/L, and 0.5 mol/L for 2 h, respectively. After immersion, the samples were removed and dried at 80 °C to obtain MnCoNi-xS catalyst samples treated with varying sulfuric acid concentrations, which were then subjected to subsequent characterization and performance testing. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The textural properties of the catalysts were characterized by N₂ physisorption measurements using a Micromeritics TriStar II Plus 3030 analyzer. Before analysis, the samples were degassed at 300 °C under vacuum for 4 h to remove surface contaminants. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded, from which the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, pore size distribution, and total pore volume were derived. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Thermo Scientific Apreo 2C) was employed to analyze the surface morphology and microstructure of the catalysts. The crystal structures of the MnCoNi-xS catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (Bruker D8 Advance, Cu Kα radiation) over a 2θ range of 10–80° at a scan rate of 6°/min. The surface chemical composition of the catalysts was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV, 400 μm spot size). The redox properties of the catalysts were probed by H₂ temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR), while the acidity characteristic was evaluated using NH₃ temperature-programmed desorption (NH₃-TPD). Both analyses were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 system. Prior to measurements, the catalyst samples were pretreated at 300 °C under an argon flow (20 mL/min) for 1 h to remove surface contaminants, followed by equilibration to ambient temperature. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed using a Bruker VERTEX 80v spectrometer. Prior to measurements, the catalyst was pretreated under N₂ flow at 300 °C for 30 min to remove surface contaminants, followed by background spectrum collection at 200 °C. To investigate the transient reaction between NO + O₂ and adsorbed NH₃, the sample was first exposed with 500 ppm NH₃ for 1 h at 200 °C. The gas flow was then switched to 500 ppm NO + 5 % O₂, while time-resolved DRIFT spectra were continuously recorded over 60 min to monitor the evolution of surface species. 2.3 Catalyst activity test A fixed-bed quartz reactor (9 mm i.d.) was loaded with 0.3 g of MnCoNi-xS catalyst (40–60 mesh). The reactant gas concentrations during testing were as follows: [NO] = 500 ppm, [H₂O] = 10 vol %, [SO₂] = 100 ppm, [O₂] = 5 vol %, [NH₃] = 500 ppm, with N₂ as balance gas. The reaction was conducted at a GHSV of 6000 h⁻¹. The mixed reactant gases were regulated using mass flow controllers. After stabilization, performance tests were conducted at different temperatures (50 °C to 350 °C). The concentrations at the inlet ([NO]in, [NH₃]in) and outlet ([NO]out, [N₂O]out, [NO₂]out) were continuously monitored using a gas analyzer. The NO conversion rate and N₂ selectivity were calculated using the following formulas: (1) N O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = [ N O ] i n − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n × 100 % (2) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t + [ N O 2 ] o u t [ N O ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 % 3 Results 3.1 SCR performance and H2O + SO2 tolerance The deNOx performance of MnCoNi-xS catalysts treated with different sulfuric acid concentrations (x = 0, 0.005, 0.01, 0.02, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 mol/L) is shown in Fig. 1 . Sulfuric acid treatment markedly improved the NO removal efficiency of MnCoNi catalysts, with all samples following a similar parabolic trend. However, differences were observed in both the temperature of maximum activity and the high-activity temperature window (defined here as the temperature range with NO conversion exceeding 90 %). The untreated MnCoNi catalyst demonstrated stable performance, maintaining 80 % NO conversion between 150–225 °C (Fig. 1a). After treatment with 0.005 mol/L sulfuric acid, the high-activity window expanded to 150–250 °C, and the NO conversion rate increased to a maximum of 95 %. The MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst displayed superior low-temperature performance with a significantly wider active temperature window. As the sulfuric acid concentration increased, the high-activity temperature range gradually narrowed. At 0.05 mol/L sulfuric acid, the temperature of maximum activity shifted from 150 °C to 200 °C, and the NO conversion rate further increased to 97 %. This indicates that appropriate sulfuric acid concentrations significantly improve the SCR activity of MnCoNi catalysts. However, when the sulfuric acid concentration reached 0.2 mol/L, the NO conversion rate declined but remained above 80 % in the 200–250 °C range. At 0.5 mol/L sulfuric acid, the enhancement effect on catalytic activity was markedly reduced, with NO conversion dropping below 80 %. This activity reduction likely stems from excessive sulfate accumulation on the catalytic surface during the acid treatment process [15]. Fig. 1b demonstrates the N₂ selectivity performance of MnCoNi-xS catalysts. All catalysts maintained nearly 100 % N₂ selectivity below 200 °C, whereas a significant decrease occurred at higher temperatures. Among them, MnCoNi-0.005S exhibited significantly superior performance compared to other catalysts. The N₂ selectivity progressively deteriorated with increasing sulfuric acid concentration, with MnCoNi-0.5S displaying the most pronounced decline at elevated temperatures. These results demonstrate that sulfuric acid concentration affects the N₂ selectivity of MnCoNi-xS catalysts. Since the MnCoNi-0.005S and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts exhibited the highest activity and optimal high-activity temperature windows among all tested samples, they were selected for further investigation in this study. In the actual denitrification process, water and sulfur dioxide are usually present, which to some extent impact the catalytic efficiency [27]. Therefore, water resistance and sulfur dioxide resistance experiments were conducted on MnCoNi, MnCoNi-0.005S, and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts at their respective optimal temperature points (175 °C, 200 °C, and 225 °C) to evaluate the effects of sulfuric acid modification on water and sulfur tolerance, as shown in Fig. 2 . The MnCoNi prepared using the solvent-free method first decreased and then increased, finally stabilizing at 80 %. Upon termination of SO2 injection, the NO conversion rate recovered and eventually stabilized at 86 %. Resuming SO₂ and H₂O introduction decreased the conversion rate to 71 %. When the gas was turned off, the NO conversion rate recovered and rose to 88 %. Both MnCoNi-0.005S and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts showed approximately 9 % reduction in NO conversion activity upon exposure to SO₂ and H₂O. However, this deactivation is reversible for the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst. The MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst fully restores its initial conversion activity upon SO₂ and H₂O removal, indicating that the toxicity did not completely deactivate the catalyst [28]. In contrast, after discontinuing SO₂ and H₂O, the MnCoNi-0.05S catalyst retained 95 % NO conversion efficiency. Our findings indicate that the MnCoNi-xS exhibits exceptional durability and resistance to H₂O + SO₂ poisoning during the water and sulfur resistance tests. 3.2 Morphological characterization 3.2.1 N2 adsorption-desorption The pore structure significantly influences catalyst activity [29]. The MnCoNi-xS catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements, with the relevant data presented in Table 1 and Fig. 3 . According to the IUPAC classification, all synthesized catalysts manifested characteristic Type IV nitrogen sorption isotherms displaying H3 hysteresis patterns (Fig. 3a), confirming the existence of mesoporous structures (2–50 nm) with irregular pore geometries [30]. Pore size distribution analysis (Fig. 3b) indicated that all three catalysts exhibited micro-mesoporous structures (1–10 nm), with average pore diameters between 4 and 9 nm (Table 1). The fresh MnCoNi catalyst showed a specific surface area of 129.189 m²/g, which increased substantially to 217.214 m²/g after treatment with 0.005 mol/L sulfuric acid. This expansion in surface area, accompanied by increased pore volume, enabled better exposure of active sites and more uniform dispersion of reactive species, thereby improving the SCR catalytic performance [31,10]. Consequently, the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst exhibited superior denitrification efficiency compared to the untreated MnCoNi, confirming that moderate sulfuric acid treatment effectively optimizes surface area. However, when the sulfuric acid concentration was further increased to 0.05 mol/L, the catalyst's surface area plummeted to 24.087 m²/g, accompanied by a sharp reduction in pore volume (0.031 cm³/g). This decline likely resulted from metal sulfate agglomeration during sulfation, which blocked existing pores and formed new superficial structures [32].These findings demonstrate that while sulfuric acid treatment alters pore structure, its impact on catalytic activity lacks a linear correlation. We hypothesize that the overall catalytic performance in this study is governed by multiple synergistic factors beyond porosity alone. 3.2.2 Surface and crystal structure study The surface morphologies of the MnCoNi, MnCoNi-0.05S, and MnCoNi-0.005S catalysts were characterized by SEM, as shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4(a, b), the untreated MnCoNi catalyst exhibits a flaky petal-like spherical morphology with a rough surface. After treatment with 0.005 mol/L sulfuric acid, the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst shows slight agglomeration while maintaining a relatively smooth surface, though the petal-like spherical structure remains discernible (Fig. 4c, d). The rough surface and moderate agglomeration provide abundant acidic sites and redox-active centers, facilitating NH3 adsorption and activation. The morphology and elemental distribution of the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst were analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 4g) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 4h–k). TEM imaging reveals well-dispersed catalyst particles with moderate aggregation but no significant agglomeration. Furthermore, EDS mapping demonstrates the homogeneous distribution of all constituent elements, corroborating the BET surface area measurements. Upon increasing the sulfuric acid concentration to 0.05 mol/L, the MnCoNi-0.05S catalyst underwent significant morphological transformation: the original petal-like spherical structure completely disappeared, replaced by large amorphous aggregates composed of densely packed small particles (Fig. 4e and 4f). This compact, irregular block-like structure with smooth surfaces substantially impeded reactant diffusion, particularly in the low-temperature regime, consequently narrowing the catalyst's active temperature window. To further investigate the effect of sulfuric acid concentration on the crystal structure of the catalysts, XRD analysis was performed in the 10–80° range, as shown in Fig. 5 . The characteristic diffraction signatures of Co₂Mn₃O₈ were observed in all catalysts, with weak peaks appearing at 18.94°, 37.49°, and 66.41°, corresponding to the (002), (211), and (231) crystal planes of Co₂Mn₃O₈ (PDF#70–0931). The catalysts treated with different sulfuric acid concentrations exhibit similar diffraction patterns to MnCoNi, indicating that sulfuric acid treatment does not alter the crystal structure. The integrated intensity of each distinct diffraction peak was quantitatively analyzed, with the results presented in Fig. 5b The analysis demonstrates that as the sulfuric acid concentration increases from 0.005 to 0.1 mol/L, the integrated peak areas for the (002), (211), and (231) crystal planes generally exhibit a decreasing trend, although localized intensity enhancements are observed at specific concentration points. These intermittent increases likely result from non-uniform acid distribution causing transient crystallinity restoration. Overall, the gradual attenuation of diffraction intensity with increasing acid concentration indicates progressive disruption of long-range crystalline order, facilitating amorphous phase formation. This structural transformation may contribute to enhanced catalytic performance by improving the dispersion of active sites [33]. Additionally, no diffraction peaks corresponding to sulfates could be detected, likely owing to their amorphous state or complete dispersion within the catalyst pores [34]. Furthermore, no diffraction peaks related to Ni-based metal oxides were detected, likely because the solvent-free preparation method without calcination resulted in poor crystallization, leaving Ni in an amorphous form [32,35]. 3.2.3 XPS The high-resolution XPS spectra in Fig. 6 characterize the Mn 2p, Ni 2p, Co 2p, and O 1 s core levels for all three catalysts (MnCoNi, MnCoNi-0.005S, and MnCoNi-0.05S), with quantitative elemental distribution data provided in Table 2 . The Mn 2p3/2 spectrum was fitted with three constituent peaks (Fig. 6a), assigned to Mn³⁺ (641.7–642 eV), Mn⁴⁺ (642.9–643.4 eV), and a satellite peak (645.4–645.6 eV) [36,37]. Quantitative analysis (Table 2) revealed that the Mn⁴⁺/(Mn³⁺+Mn⁴⁺) ratio in MnCoNi-0.005S (57.4 %) was slightly higher than those in MnCoNi (56.4 %) and MnCoNi-0.05S (51.8 %).The Ni 2p3/2 spectrum (Fig. 6b) was fitted with three peaks at 855.2–855.5 eV (Ni²⁺), 856.3–856.9 eV (Ni³⁺), and 861–861.8 eV (satellite peak) [38]. Similar to the Mn 2p3/2 results, MnCoNi-0.005S exhibited the highest Ni³⁺/(Ni²⁺+Ni³⁺) ratio (52.5 %). The Co 2p3/2 (Fig. 6c) signal contained Co²⁺ (781.7–782.5 eV), Co³⁺ (780.1–780.3 eV), and a satellite peak (785.9–788.6 eV) [24,39]. Co³⁺, as a redox-active center, is essential for NH₃ adsorption and activation [40]. Notably, after treatment with 0.005 mol/L sulfuric acid, the Co³⁺/(Co²⁺ + Co³⁺) ratio significantly decreased to 52.1 %, indicating a reduction in Co³⁺ relative content. However, the binding energies of both Co²⁺ and Co³⁺ in the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst were lower than those in the pristine MnCoNi catalyst, suggesting enhanced reactivity of cobalt ions in MnCoNi-0.005S, which facilitates the SCR reaction process more effectively [41]. The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 6d) was resolved into adsorbed oxygen (Oα, 531.2–531.3 eV) and lattice oxygen (Oβ, 529.5–529.8 eV) [42]. Numerous studies have demonstrated that chemisorbed oxygen species (Oα) exhibit higher reactivity than lattice oxygen (Oβ) due to their superior mobility. This enhanced mobility facilitates the oxidation of NO to NO₂ and accelerates the fast SCR reaction pathway, thereby improving the overall catalytic efficiency [43]. As presented in Table 2, all MnCoNi-xS catalysts show relatively high concentrations of chemisorbed oxygen. Particularly, the catalyst treated with 0.005 mol/L sulfuric acid achieves the highest Oα/(Oα + Oβ) ratio (70.3 %), which is notably greater than those of the untreated MnCoNi (68.4 %) and MnCoNi-0.05S (68.3 %) catalysts. In summary, Mn⁴⁺, Ni³⁺, and Oα serve as favorable species for enhancing redox properties, which promote SCR activity by accelerating the fast SCR reaction pathway [9,17,38]. The MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst exhibits higher relative contents of Mn⁴⁺, Ni³⁺, and Oα compared to the pristine MnCoNi, which likely contributes to its superior catalytic activity. In contrast, MnCoNi-0.05S shows reduced Mn⁴⁺, Ni³⁺, Co³⁺, and Oα levels, accompanied by binding energy shifts toward higher fields, possibly due to sulfation induced by sulfuric acid treatment. However, despite these reductions, MnCoNi-0.05S still maintains good catalytic activity. This anomalous phenomenon may arise from the significant enhancement of surface acidity caused by sulfuric acid treatment. NH₃-TPD analysis reveals that acid-treated catalysts develop new acidic sites in the low-temperature region (150–300 °C). 3.3 Redox properties Redox properties were evaluated by H₂-TPR from 200 to 700 °C, with reduction profiles shown in Fig. 7 . The peak temperatures and H₂ consumption are summarized in Table 3 . The MnCoNi and MnCoNi-0.005S catalysts exhibited two reduction peaks, while MnCoNi-0.05S displayed four distinct reduction peaks. The temperature window of 349–365 °C reflects the combined reduction processes of Mn₂O₃→Mn₃O₄ and Co³⁺→Co²⁺ [36,44], while the 423–458 °C range represents transformations involving Mn₃O₄→MnO, Co²⁺→Co⁰, and Ni³⁺/Ni²⁺→Ni⁰ [45,46]. Although the H₂-TPR profile of MnCoNi-0.005S was similar to that of MnCoNi, its higher H₂ consumption suggests increased amounts of easily reducible species, consistent with the XPS results (Table 2). For MnCoNi-0.05S, the low-temperature peak at 299 °C is assigned to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn₂O₃ [17]. In contrast, with increasing sulfuric acid concentration, MnCoNi-0.05S developed a new reduction peak at 523 °C with progressive high-temperature shifting, indicating weakened redox capability. However, its substantially greater H₂ consumption relative to the other two catalysts may stem from SO₄²⁻ reduction to SO₂ [15]. 3.4 Surface acidity Given the pivotal role of surface acidity in NH₃-SCR systems [15], we systematically evaluated acid site distribution through NH₃-TPD before and after sulfuric acid treatment (Fig. 8a ). The low-temperature peak (100–300 °C) corresponds to NH₃ desorption from weak acid sites, the intermediate-temperature peak (300–500 °C) originates from medium-strength acid sites, while the high-temperature peak (>500 °C) reflects NH₃ desorption from strong acid sites [47–49]. Quantitative analysis of acid site concentrations based on NH₃-TPD curve integration is presented in Table 4 . Evidently, the MnCoNi catalyst exhibits three weak desorption peaks at 150 °C, 352 °C, and 527 °C, representing weak, medium, and strong acid sites, respectively. The minimal peak area indicates its limited NH₃ adsorption capacity. After sulfuric acid treatment, the desorption peak intensities significantly increase and the peak areas become much larger than those of MnCoNi, demonstrating remarkable enhancement of both weak and medium-strength acid sites along with increased acid site density. The MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst manifests four desorption features across the experimental temperature window, where the low-temperature peaks (147 °C, 278 °C) are characteristic of weak acid sites, while 332 °C and 503 °C signals represent medium-strength acid sites. Notably, MnCoNi-0.05S shows four desorption peaks in the low-to-medium temperature range with higher overall peak intensity and larger peak area, indicating more abundant surface acid sites. These results confirm that sulfuric acid treatment effectively enhances catalyst surface acidity, where stronger surface acidity facilitates NH₃ adsorption. Combined with In situ DRIFT results, the treatment introduces HSO₄⁻ as acid sites while maintaining Lewis acid sites [24], synergistically promoting SCR performance. This fundamentally explains the excellent NH₃-SCR activity observed for both MnCoNi-0.005S and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts. To elucidate the superior water/sulfur resistance of MnCoNi, MnCoNi-0.005S, and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts, NH₃-TPD analysis was performed on sulfated samples (S-MnCoNi, 0.005S-MnCoNi, and 0.05S-MnCoNi). To elucidate the superior water/sulfur resistance of the MnCoNi, MnCoNi-0.005S, and MnCoNi-0.05S catalysts, NH₃-TPD analysis was performed on their sulfated counterparts (denoted as S-MnCoNi, S-MnCoNi-0.005S, and S-MnCoNi-0.05S, respectively). Fig. 8b reveals that S-MnCoNi exhibits stronger desorption peaks than pristine MnCoNi, indicating enhanced acid site concentration and strength during SO₂ + H₂O exposure, which explains the recovered NO conversion after stopping SO₂ + H₂O supply, consistent with SCR performance. The 0.005S-MnCoNi catalyst exhibits an increased quantity of acid sites, along with low-temperature-shifted desorption peaks, which enables activity recovery after SO₂ + H₂O cutoff. In contrast, 0.05S-MnCoNi shows a reduction in both the quantity and type of acid sites following SO₂ + H₂O treatment, resulting in poorer resistance. These results demonstrate that optimal sulfate concentration increases medium/weak acid sites, where HSO₄⁻ groups serve as additional NH₃ adsorption sites [24], thereby improving both anti-poisoning capability and SCR performance. 3.5 In situ drift study Fig. 9(a) displays the temporal evolution of the reaction between pre-adsorbed NH₃ species and NO + O₂ on the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst surface at 200 °C. after 1 hour of NH3 pre-adsorption, characteristic peaks at 1611, 1202, and 1549 cm⁻¹ were observed on the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst, attributed to NH3 coordinated to Lewis acid sites, while the peak at 1344 cm⁻¹ was assigned to the SOH bending vibration of HSO4 ⁻, and the peak at 1421 cm⁻¹ corresponded to NH4+ species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites [22,28,50]. Upon introducing NO + O2, the NH3-related peaks rapidly diminished and disappeared, while new peaks associated with monodentate nitrate (1279 cm⁻¹), bidentate nitrate (1592 cm⁻¹), and bridging nitrate (1633 cm⁻¹) emerged [37,43,51,52]. Notably, the peak at 1559 cm⁻¹ initially appeared and then disappeared over time, indicating the transient instability and subsequent oxidation of this nitrate intermediate into a stable form. For the MnCoNi-0.05S catalyst at 250 °C (Fig. 9(b)), weaker absorption bands corresponding to NH3 on Lewis acid sites (1612, 1228, and 1145 cm⁻¹) were observed after NH3 pre-adsorption, alongside peaks for NH4+ on Brønsted acid sites (1417 cm⁻¹) and SOH bending vibrations of HSO4 ⁻ (1349 cm⁻¹). Upon NO + O2 introduction, the 1417 cm⁻¹ and 1349 cm⁻¹ peaks overlapped with nitrate species, suggesting partial participation of Brønsted acid site-adsorbed NH4⁺ and HSO4 ⁻ in the reaction. The DRIFT analysis reveals distinct reactive species distributions between the two catalysts: MnCoNi-0.005S exhibits NH₃ coordinated to Lewis acid sites and NH4+ ions stabilized at Brønsted acid sites, while MnCoNi-0.05S mainly contains Brønsted acid-adsorbed NH4⁺ along with HSO4 ⁻ species. In both catalytic systems, NH3 molecules adsorbed on both types of acid sites actively participate in the SCR process. It is noteworthy that upon introducing NO + O₂, both NH₃ species on Lewis acid sites and NH₄⁺ on Brønsted acid sites were rapidly consumed, accompanied by the dynamic formation and transformation of various NOₓ-adsorbed species (such as monodentate/bidentate nitrates). This observation clearly demonstrates that during the NH₃-SCR reaction, gaseous NO can directly react with adsorbed NH₃/NH₄⁺ species via the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism, while adsorbed NOₓ species can also interact with neighboring NH₃/NH₄⁺ through the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) pathway. Sulfation treatment significantly enhances the surface acidity (particularly Brønsted acidity) of the catalysts, thereby improving their NH₃ adsorption capacity [53]. The incorporation of HSO₄⁻ not only strengthens Brønsted acidity and stabilizes NH₄⁺ adsorption, but may also facilitate intermediate conversion in the l-H pathway by forming surface sulfate-nitrate composite sites. These results suggest that the NH₃-SCR reaction over MnCoNi-S catalysts proceeds through a synergistic combination of both Eley-Rideal (E-R) and Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanisms. 4 Conclusion MnCoNi-xS catalysts were prepared by treating the MnCoNi catalyst with sulfuric acid at different concentrations. The results demonstrate that the MnCoNi-xS catalysts exhibit excellent water and sulfur resistance. The SCR activity of MnCoNi-xS catalysts treated with sulfuric acid at varying concentrations is influenced, with the series of acid-treated catalysts exhibiting distinct high-activity temperatures and active temperature ranges(>90 %). Notably, the MnCoNi-0.005S catalyst demonstrates exceptional performance across a relatively wide low-temperature operation window (150–250 °C). This enhancement is primarily attributed to sulfuric acid treatment-induced modifications, including a significantly increased specific surface area, enriched redox species, enhanced activity of easily reducible species, elevated surface-chemisorbed active oxygen, and heightened surface acidity. In contrast, the MnCoNi-0.05S catalyst shows a shifted high-activity window to higher temperatures (200–250 °C) with weaker redox properties, yet maintained favorable SCR performance. Combined characterization results suggest this can be ascribed to the moderate sulfuric acid concentration increasing medium-low acid site quantities, where HSO4 ⁻ generated during sulfation acts as acid sites for NH3 adsorption. The enhanced surface acidity promotes ammonia adsorption, thereby improving the catalyst's selective catalytic reduction (SCR) activity. coredata.dc:description: Mn-based catalysts exhibit remarkable NH3-SCR activity. However, their single-component oxides are limited by insufficient surface acidity and poor resistance to H2O and SO2. Therefore, enhancing their surface acidity and improving their resistance to water and sulfur is a meaningful research topic. A series of MnCoNi-xS catalysts were fabricated through treatment of MnCoNi (prepared via a solvent-free method) with sulfuric acid at varying concentrations. This study methodically examines how varying concentrations of sulfuric acid affect the SCR activity and H2O and SO2 durability of MnCoNi ternary catalysts. The comprehensive characterization analyses demonstrate that applying varied concentrations of sulfuric acid during treatment can generate differentiated high-activity domains. Appropriate sulfuric acid treatment can enhance the surface acidity, specific surface area, and redox properties of MnCoNi catalysts, thereby promoting their denitrification performance. Ultimately, the MnCoNi-xS catalyst ​maintained exceptional catalytic activity even under prolonged exposure to H₂O and SO₂.

coredata.dc:title: Optimizing the NH3-SCR activity of Mn-based catalysts via sulfuric acid concentration-controlled treatments
